headline: Why Nvidia (NVDA) Stock Is Declining Again Today
summary: NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ: NVDA) shares continued to slide on Tuesday, falling more than 3% after a Chinese regulator announced that it was investigating the chipmaker for possible violations of the country’s antimonopoly law. On Monday, December 9, the Chinese government announced that The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) had initiated an investigation concerning Nvidia’s acquisition […]

headline: Apple market cap, momentum, MicroStrategy: Market Takeaways
summary: After US market indexes (^DJI, ^IXIC, ^GSPC) closed in negative territory for the second session in a row, Apple's (AAPL) market cap crossed past a record $3.7 trillion. Yahoo Finance markets and data editor Jared Blikre joins Josh Lipton on Asking for a Trend to explain the trading day's biggest themes, including Apple's new market cap, momentum reversal patterns, and MicroStrategy's (MSTR) stock activity in relation to bitcoin (BTC-USD). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: The Year’s Best Dow Stock Not Named Nvidia
summary: Walmart  customers consider the retailer a happy place because of its low prices and “rollback” sales.  Nvidia  is the only stock in the  this year that has done better than Walmart, soaring nearly 175%.  The nearly unanimous answer from analysts is yes; 37 of the 41 sell-siders who follow the stock have Walmart rated a “Buy” or “Outperform,” compared with just three “Holds” and one “Sell.”

headline: Nvidia Turns Lower, Dragging Down the Major Indexes
summary: The S&P 500 was hovering around breakeven and the Nasdaq Composite was up just 0.2% shortly after noon ET.  The Dow was up 22 points, or less than 0.1%.  Nvidia stock was down 1.8%, while the SOXX ETF was down 2%.

headline: Cloudflare expected to deal with 'a variety' of chip providers: CTO
summary: While AI demand continues to strengthen across industries — worrying Wall Street over whether chipmakers and operators can meet this demand — Cloudflare (NET) Chief Technology Officer John Graham-Cumming finds that "what we're seeing is the real growth of actual AI applications." Graham-Cumming sits down with Seana Smith and Madison Mills on Yahoo Finance's Catalysts for a conversation about the broader AI landscape, including the heightened demand for Nvidia's (NVDA) landmark chips going into 2025. "Obviously, Nvidia really is absolutely by far the market leader. But we continue to look at other chip manufacturers, other chips that are out there. And I fully expect over the next few years that within the Cloudflare network, there will be a variety of different providers for a variety of different types of models," the Cloudflare CTO states. Graham-Cumming comments on the likelihood that his company will rely on several chip providers. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Nvidia Stock Gains. What TSMC Sales, China Probe Mean for Chip Maker.
summary: Nvidia stock rose Tuesday on the back of a sales boost for the chip maker’s key manufacturer, helping lift the shadow of an antitrust investigation in China.  Nvidia  shares were up 1.6% at $141.08 in early trading, as it continues in its range of between $135 and $145 of the past few weeks.  The stock fell 2.6% on Monday after China’s State Administration for Market Regulation said it had initiated an investigation into Nvidia due to a suspected violation of antimonopoly law.

headline: Taiwan Semi November Revenue Ups 34% Strengthened by AI and Smartphone Demand
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (NYSE:TSM) reported a topline growth of 34% year-on-year to $8.55 billion in November 2024. Revenue for January through November 2024 grew by 31.8% year over year to $81.05 billion, testimony to the continued artificial intelligence frenzy. The contract chipmaker’s market share grew to 64.9%, up from 62.3% Q/Q, helping it retain the top position in the global wafer foundry business. This is due to the smartphone and AI-related demand for its 3nm and 5nm tech

raw.headline: Taiwan Semi November Revenue Ups 34% Strengthened by AI and Smartphone Demand
raw.summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (NYSE:TSM) reported a topline growth of 34% year-on-year to $8.55 billion in November 2024. The contract chipmaker’s market share grew to 64.9%, up from 62.3% Q/Q, helping it retain the top position in the global wafer foundry business. This is due to the smartphone and AI-related demand for its 3nm and 5nm tech

headline: Prediction: This Artificial Intelligence (AI) Chip Stock Is Going to Skyrocket After Dec. 12
summary: There is no doubt that Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) is the dominant player in the market for artificial intelligence (AI) chips, as its graphics processing units (GPUs) have played a central role in training popular AI models such as ChatGPT and Llama.  As a result, Nvidia's data center revenue rose by a remarkable 112% year over year in the third quarter of its fiscal 2025 to a record $30.8 billion, while AMD's revenue from this segment came in at just $3.5 billion in its most recently reported quarter.  At the same time, some investors seem a tad concerned about the relative slowdown in Nvidia's growth.
